name: Matcha Tiramisu
description: Creamy, rich, and bursting with flavor, this irresistible Matcha Tiramisu layers green tea-soaked ladyfingers with a light and airy mascarpone cream. It’s a modern Japanese twist on the classic Italian dessert. The vibrant green pop of color will wow your guests at your next party.
recipeIngredient: 3  large egg yolks ((one egg yolk is about 19 g; at room temperature))
2 Tbsp marsala wine ((highly recommend; missing a kick without it; can substitute with dark rum or brandy))
24  ladyfingers ((divided, for 2 layers; you will need 36 cookies for 3 layers; read the post))

itemListElement.text: Please note that this is a chilled dessert and requires at least 4 hours of chilling time, preferably overnight.
itemListElement.name: Please note that this is a chilled dessert and requires at least 4 hours of chilling time, preferably overnight.

itemListElement.text: Gather all the ingredients and equipment.
itemListElement.name: Gather all the ingredients and equipment.

itemListElement.text: You will need a medium saucepan, a medium heatproof mixing bowl to set over the saucepan, and two large bowls. Fill one of the large bowls with water and ice and make sure that the mixing bowl fits in this ice bath; set aside for cooling the egg mixture later. Also, set an instant-read thermometer near the double boiler in the next step.
itemListElement.name: You will need a medium saucepan, a medium heatproof mixing bowl to set over the saucepan, and two large bowls. Fill one of the large bowls with water and ice and make sure that the mixing bowl fits in this ice bath; set aside for cooling the egg mixture later. Also, set an instant-read thermometer near the double boiler in the next step.

itemListElement.text: Set up a double boiler. First, add 2 inches of water to the saucepan. Next, set the mixing bowl on top and check that the bottom of the bowl does not touch the water. Set aside the mixing bowl to use for the egg mixture. Bring the water to a bare simmer over medium heat, then reduce the heat to low.
itemListElement.name: Set up a double boiler. First, add 2 inches of water to the saucepan. Next, set the mixing bowl on top and check that the bottom of the bowl does not touch the water. Set aside the mixing bowl to use for the egg mixture. Bring the water to a bare simmer over medium heat, then reduce the heat to low.

itemListElement.text: In the medium heatproof mixing bowl, add 3 large egg yolks, 2 Tbsp marsala wine, and 3 Tbsp of the ⅓ cup sugar. Start whisking it with a handheld electric mixer.
itemListElement.name: In the medium heatproof mixing bowl, add 3 large egg yolks, 2 Tbsp marsala wine, and 3 Tbsp of the ⅓ cup sugar. Start whisking it with a handheld electric mixer.

itemListElement.text: Set the bowl over the saucepan of barely simmering water and continue to beat the egg yolks. Over the next 10 minutes or so, you‘ll gently cook this egg mixture until it registers 160ºF (71ºC), when it‘s safe to consume. Keep your instant-read thermometer handy to check the temperature. Tip: At around 160ºF, your eggs may turn into scrambled eggs; therefore, I highly recommend both an electric mixer and an instant-read thermometer for this process (please read my post).
itemListElement.name: Set the bowl over the saucepan of barely simmering water and continue to beat the egg yolks. Over the next 10 minutes or so, you‘ll gently cook this egg mixture until it registers 160ºF (71ºC), when it‘s safe to consume. Keep your instant-read thermometer handy to check the temperature. Tip: At around 160ºF, your eggs may turn into scrambled eggs; therefore, I highly recommend both an electric mixer and an instant-read thermometer for this process (please read my post).

itemListElement.text: Continue to cook the egg mixture, beating it constantly. The egg mixture will increase in volume and becoming lighter in texture. It also will turn a pale yellow color.
itemListElement.name: Continue to cook the egg mixture, beating it constantly. The egg mixture will increase in volume and becoming lighter in texture. It also will turn a pale yellow color.

itemListElement.text: Continue whisking. I use Speed 3 of a 5-speed hand mixer throughout this process. Continue to check the temperature.
itemListElement.name: Continue whisking. I use Speed 3 of a 5-speed hand mixer throughout this process. Continue to check the temperature.

itemListElement.text: As soon as the egg mixture reaches 160ºF (71ºC), immediately remove the mixing bowl from the saucepan. Set the bowl in the ice bath to quickly stop the cooking. Let it cool for 1 minute.
itemListElement.name: As soon as the egg mixture reaches 160ºF (71ºC), immediately remove the mixing bowl from the saucepan. Set the bowl in the ice bath to quickly stop the cooking. Let it cool for 1 minute.

itemListElement.text: Meanwhile, put 8 oz mascarpone cheese in another large bowl and soften it with a silicone spatula. Add the cooled egg mixture into the bowl with the mascarpone.
itemListElement.name: Meanwhile, put 8 oz mascarpone cheese in another large bowl and soften it with a silicone spatula. Add the cooled egg mixture into the bowl with the mascarpone.

itemListElement.text: Note: The egg mixture does get cooked a bit on the sides of the bowl from the double boiler. Do not scrape off or use this cooked egg in your mascarpone mixture.
itemListElement.name: Note: The egg mixture does get cooked a bit on the sides of the bowl from the double boiler. Do not scrape off or use this cooked egg in your mascarpone mixture.

itemListElement.text: Gently fold the egg mixture into the mascarpone until just smooth. Tip: The egg mixture will become grainy if overmixed.
itemListElement.name: Gently fold the egg mixture into the mascarpone until just smooth. Tip: The egg mixture will become grainy if overmixed.

itemListElement.text: Now, make the whipped cream: In another bowl, beat 1½ cups heavy (whipping) cream until foamy; you can reuse the bowl from the ice bath, but make sure it‘s completely dry. Then, gradually add the rest of the sugar.
itemListElement.name: Now, make the whipped cream: In another bowl, beat 1½ cups heavy (whipping) cream until foamy; you can reuse the bowl from the ice bath, but make sure it‘s completely dry. Then, gradually add the rest of the sugar.

itemListElement.text: Beat together until medium peaks form. The cream holds its shape well but is still soft and hasn’t started to become grainy. When you lift out the whisk, peaks will form but they will bend over at the end.
itemListElement.name: Beat together until medium peaks form. The cream holds its shape well but is still soft and hasn’t started to become grainy. When you lift out the whisk, peaks will form but they will bend over at the end.

itemListElement.text: Now, gently fold the whipped cream mixture into the mascarpone mixture.
itemListElement.name: Now, gently fold the whipped cream mixture into the mascarpone mixture.

itemListElement.text: Fold the mascarpone cream until well combined.
itemListElement.name: Fold the mascarpone cream until well combined.

itemListElement.text: In a small bowl, combine ½ cup water (heated to 175ºF/80ºC) and 1½ Tbsp matcha (green tea powder). Whisk together until there are no lumps. Transfer this matcha mixture to a flat-bottomed container big enough for a ladyfinger cookie to lay flat.
itemListElement.name: In a small bowl, combine ½ cup water (heated to 175ºF/80ºC) and 1½ Tbsp matcha (green tea powder). Whisk together until there are no lumps. Transfer this matcha mixture to a flat-bottomed container big enough for a ladyfinger cookie to lay flat.

itemListElement.text: Gather 24 ladyfingers. One at a time, quickly dip a ladyfinger into the matcha mixture until soaked but not soggy; use a pair of tongs to flip it over to soak the other side. Then, place it on the bottom of an 8 x 8-inch (20 x 20 cm) baking dish. Repeat until you‘ve arranged 2 rows of 6 ladyfingers each.
itemListElement.name: Gather 24 ladyfingers. One at a time, quickly dip a ladyfinger into the matcha mixture until soaked but not soggy; use a pair of tongs to flip it over to soak the other side. Then, place it on the bottom of an 8 x 8-inch (20 x 20 cm) baking dish. Repeat until you‘ve arranged 2 rows of 6 ladyfingers each.

itemListElement.text: Spread half of the mascarpone cream over the ladyfingers in an even layer. Smooth out the surface using the silicone spatula or a silicone pastry scraper.
itemListElement.name: Spread half of the mascarpone cream over the ladyfingers in an even layer. Smooth out the surface using the silicone spatula or a silicone pastry scraper.

itemListElement.text: Create a second layer of cookies, dipping the remaining ladyfingers in the matcha mixture and placing them in 2 neat rows on top of the mascarpone cream layer.
itemListElement.name: Create a second layer of cookies, dipping the remaining ladyfingers in the matcha mixture and placing them in 2 neat rows on top of the mascarpone cream layer.

itemListElement.text: Top with the remaining cream and smooth out the top. Cover with a sheet of plastic wrap placed directly on the surface of the cream to prevent a skin from forming. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
itemListElement.name: Top with the remaining cream and smooth out the top. Cover with a sheet of plastic wrap placed directly on the surface of the cream to prevent a skin from forming. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.

itemListElement.text: Remove your chilled Matcha Tiramisu from the refrigerator and unwrap the plastic. Immediately before serving, dust 2 Tbsp matcha (green tea powder) on top of the tiramisu using a fine-mesh sieve. Enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Remove your chilled Matcha Tiramisu from the refrigerator and unwrap the plastic. Immediately before serving, dust 2 Tbsp matcha (green tea powder) on top of the tiramisu using a fine-mesh sieve. Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

review.reviewBody: Made the tiramisu! turned out amazing. left out the rum but still tasted great! it was decadent, and even though I used stale ladyfingers. I used it for a potluck and it was completely devoured! I saw people scraping the bottom of the pan. Thank you so much for this recipe!
Made a similar pud but used Sake for the kick, I used raw egg.
Thank you for the amazing recipe! it was a hit!
